questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with rigidity, frequent falls, slow movements, tremors, and a short stepping gait when he entered the doctor's room. Which of the following areas is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease, which is associated with the degeneration of substantia nigra (marked as "C").

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Postural instability along with bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Notable gait abnormalities are:

  • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
  • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
  • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
  • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness
  • Wide stepping gait - cerebellar dysfunction

questions.text: A 50-year-old male was diagnosed with a submandibular gland tumour and posted for surgical removal of the gland along with its duct. Following surgery, he developed loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the taste sensations are present. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
General sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by lingual nerve, which is likely to be inujured in this case.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue,

  • General sensation is carried by the lingual nerve.
  • Taste sensation is carried by chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue,

  • Both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngealnerve.

Valleculae is supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

Special sensory

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Posterior most tongue (vallecullae, epiglottis)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

questions.text: The gluteus maximus muscle is attached to ________
questions.solution:
The gluteus maximus muscle is attached to the iliotibial tract of the fascia lata.

Origin:

  • Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium, posterior to posterior gluteal line
  • Posterior superior iliac spine
  • Posterior aspect of sacrum and coccyx
  • Sacrotuberous ligament.

Insertion - It is inserted mainly in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal tuberosity on the posterior femoral surface.

Action:

  • Major extensor of hip joint
  • Lateral rotation of hip joint
  • Active in powerful abduction of thigh

Arterial Supply - Inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the profunda femoris artery.

Nerve Supply- Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1 and S2).

Note:

The fascia lata is a deep fascial investment of the whole thigh musculature.

The iliotibial tract is a longitudinal thickening of the fascia lata, which is strengthened posteriorly by fibres from the gluteus maximus.

questions.text: A child is starting to walk and gaining upright posture. Which of the following spinal curvatures develops secondarily due to the development of this function?
questions.solution:
Lumbar curvature develops secondarily when the child starts walking and gaining upright posture.

Both the primary curves (thoracic and pelvic) that appear during embryonic life are convex dorsally. After birth, functional muscle development results in the appearance of secondary cervical and lumbar spinal curvatures in the sagittal plane.

  • The secondary cervical curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles responsible for the head extension.
  • The secondary lumbar curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles responsible for sitting upright and walking.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is most likely to be injured in a wrist slash injury over the radial side of the left wrist?
questions.solution:
Median nerve is more likey to be injured in case of deep laceration of radial side of the wrist.

Wrist slash injuries:

A deep laceration on the radial side of the wrist may injure the radial artery, median nerve, flexor carpi radialis tendon, and palmaris longus tendon.

A deep laceration on the ulnar side of the wrist may injure the ulnar artery, ulnar nerve, and flexor carpi ulnaris tendon.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked area is pterygoid fovea where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion and side to side movement of the jaw.

In addition, lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted to the articular disc and capsule of TMJ.

Masseter muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of zygomatic bone and zygomatic arch.
  • Insertion - It inserted into the lateral surface of ramus of the mandible and coronoid process

Temporalis muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from the temporal fossa and deep surface of temporal fascia.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the coronoid process and to the anterior border of the ramus of the mandible up to the third molar tooth.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and articular disc.

 Medial pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Deep head arises from medial surface of lateral pterygoid plate and pyramidal process of palatine bone. Superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
  • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of mandible

questions.text: The muscle marked as " B" in the image is ______ and is innervated by ______
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is inferior oblique and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

All the extraocular muscles (including inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

questions.text: Which of the following dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary?
questions.solution:
The venous sinus marked with 'B' in the given image is the straight sinus. The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

The straight sinus is a continuation of the inferior sagittal sinus. It lies in the junction of the falx cerebri with tentorium cerebelli. The straight sinus further drains into one of the transverse sinuses (mostly the left).

Other options

A - Superior sagittal sinus

C - Superior petrosal sinus

D - Sigmoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is supplied by the structure marked as D in the following image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as D is the recurrent laryngeal nerve. It supplies posterior cricoarytenoid muscle which is an intrinsic muscle of the larynx. All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve except for cricothyroid, which is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

In the given image, other structures marked are:

  • A – vagus
  • B – Sympathetic trunk
  • C – Phrenic nerve

The cervical part of sympathetic trunk lies anterior to longus colli and longus capitis muscles (enclosed in prevertebral fascia) and posterior to the common carotid artery. Sympathetic trunk lies outside the carotid sheath.

Other options:

Option A: Trapezius is supplied by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI).

Option C: Cricothyroid is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

Option D: Diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve.

questions.text: Hydration level of cornea is a primary function of?
questions.solution:
The hydration level of the cornea is maintained mainly by the endothelial cells of the cornea.

Endothelium possesses Na+/K+ ATPase, which keeps the corneal stroma in a relatively dehydrated state. This helps in maintaining the transparency of the cornea.

Other factors contributing to the transparency of the cornea are as follows:

  • Regular arrangement of corneal lamellae (Maurice theory)
  • Peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory)
  • Avascularity of the cornea
  • A balance between the intraocular pressure (IOP) and swelling pressure

questions.text: Ligation of common hepatic artery will impair blood supply in:

choices.text: Right  gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.solution:
Ligation of the common hepatic artery will cause impairment in the blood supply through its branches i.e right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery.

Blood supply of the stomach:

The arterial supply of the stomach is contributed exclusively by the branches of the celiac trunk. They are:

  • Left gastric artery - Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  • Splenic artery- This further divides into:
    • Short gastric arteries- Supplies the fundus of the stomach
    • Left gastroepiploic artery- Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach
  • Common hepatic artery, which gives the following branches
    • Right gastric artery- Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
    • Gastroduodenal artery- Right gastroepiploic artery arises from this and supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.

questions.text: The reason for long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which arch artery?
questions.solution:
The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the left 6th arch artery.

  • During the development, the laryngeal nerves initially arise below the 6th arch artery and cross here to innervate the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.
  • As the larynx moves cranially relative to the aortic arch arteries, the recurrent laryngeal nerves on right and left sides are caught under the 6th arch arteries.
  • Now, on the right side, the distal 6th arch artery disappears, and since there is no 5th arch artery, the right recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under the 4th arch artery which becomes the future right subclavian artery.
  • On the left side, the 6th arch artery persists, which develops into ductus arteriosus, which later forms ligamentum arteriosum. Due to the persistence of the 6th arch artery, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under it and therefore, has a relatively long course.

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player was brought to the hospital after he suffered an ​injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee joint. MRI revealed the injury to the ligaments commonly referred to as the unhappy triad. Which of the following ligament is not involved in the unhappy triad?
questions.solution:
The ligaments involved in the unhappy triad of knee joint are medial meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament, and tibial collateral ligament. It is also known as O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle.

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called as – O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to lateral blow to the knee. It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

Image: Unhappy triad injury in MRI (after O'Donoghue) of the knee joint (PDW SPIR). Left to right: Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament, rupture of the medial collateral ligament, and inner meniscal tear (here complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: Identify the marked artery.
questions.solution:
The artery marked is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This artery branches out from the vertebral artery and it is the largest branch of the vertebral artery.

The following image shows the circle of Willis.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: Thoracic duct does not drain:
questions.solution:
The right upper quadrant of the body drains the lymphatics into the right lymphatic trunk and rest of the body drains into the thoracic duct.

Thoracic duct begins in the abdomen at T-12 vertebral level as the continuation of cisterna chyli.

  • It is usually beaded due to its numerous valves.
  • It drains the body below the diaphragm (lower limbs, pelvis, abdomen) and left half of the body above the diaphragm (thorax, upper limb, head and neck).
  • Thoracic duct passes through the aortic hiatus in the diaphragm and ascends through the posterior mediastinum between the aorta and the azygous vein.
  • At T-5 level, it deviates to the left side and ascends to pass the thoracic inlet.

Tributaries of the thoracic duct:

  • Bilateral (right and left) descending thoracic lymph trunks which convey lymph from lower intercostal spaces (6 – 11).
  • Left upper intercostal lymph trunks, which convey lymph from the upper intercostal spaces (1-5).
  • Mediastinal lymph trunks
  • Left subclavian lymph trunk
  • Left jugular lymph trunk
  • Left bronchomediastinal lymph trunk

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

questions.text: A thyroid mass usually moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by which of the following fascia:

choices.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
A thyroid mass usually moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by the pre-tracheal fascia.

Pre-tracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. The posteromedial aspects of the thyroid lobes are attached to the side of the cricoid cartilage by Berry’s ligament which is formed by the condensation of pretracheal fascia. It is responsible for the movement of thyroid mass with swallowing.

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

  • The investing layer which splits to enclose the parotid and submandibular gland. It also forms the roof of the posterior triangle.
  • The pretracheal layer which encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either sides forms suspensory ligament which is known as ligament of Berry.
  • The carotid sheath which is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses the common and internal carotid arteries, internal jugular vein and vagus nerve.
  • The prevertebral fascia which forms the axillary sheath.
  • Buccopharyngeal fascia
  • Pharyngobasilar fascia

questions.text: All of the following muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except?
questions.solution:
Palatoglossus is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve.

All intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes (hence innervated by the hypoglossal nerve), except palatoglossus, which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the vago-accessory nerve.

Note:

  • All the muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus (cranial accessory nerve through pharyngeal plexus) are supplied by hypoglossal nerve.
  • All the muscles of pharynx except stylopharyngeus (glossopharyngeal nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of soft palate except tensor veli palatini (nerve to medial pterygoid from mandibular nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid (external laryngeal nerve) are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 23-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the hospital with a history of abdominal pain, dehydration, weakness, and lethargy. Which of the following kidney segments is associated with maximum water reabsorption?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule is the site of maximum water reabsorption about 67% of the filtered water.

The driving force for water reabsorption is a trans tubular osmotic gradient established by the reabsorption of solutes.

Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): Sodium is reabsorbed along with various inorganic and organic substances- chloride, bicarbonate, phosphate, lactate, glucose, and amino acids. In the early PCT, the main sodium channels used for reabsorption are Na+-glucose cotransporter (SGLT), Na+-H+ exchanger, Na+-amino acid cotransporter, Na+-phosphate cotransporter. In the distal PCT, the high chloride concentration in the lumen favors NaCl reabsorption, driven by the Cl− gradient. 

Based on the ultrastructure proximal tubule is divided into three segments:

  • S1 segment: 1st half of PCT
  • S2 segment: 2nd half of PCT and 1st half of proximal straight tubule
  • S3 segment: 2nd half of proximal straight tubule

The dilution of urine in water diuresis mainly occurs in the distal parts of the nephron. The proximal convoluted tubule absorbs water and solutes in equal proportions, while the descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to only water. As a result, the urine is concentrated as it enters the ascending limb.

The ascending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to water. There is reabsorption of solutes and thus, urine gets diluted. In the absence of vasopressin seen in water diuresis, the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct also remain impermeable to water, while sodium continues to get reabsorbed. Urine becomes hypo-osmolar to plasma. Thus, a large volume of dilute urine is excreted.

In chronic alcoholics, the production and release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, can be impaired. Alcohol inhibits the secretion of ADH from the pituitary gland. This leads to a decreased ability to concentrate urine and increases diuresis, resulting in excessive loss of water. Consequently, the kidneys reabsorb less water, causing dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Over time, chronic suppression of ADH can lead to persistent polyuria and the risk of developing chronic dehydration and electrolyte disturbances, such as hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has had perfectly normal cycles every month since her puberty. Which of the following pattern of hormones is expected in the proliferative phase, around the time of ovulation, and luteal phase respectively?

choices.text: High progesterone, high FSH, high estradiol
Increasing estradiol, high FSH, low inhibin A
Increasing FSH, LH surge, low estradiol
Increasing estradiol, high FSH, high inhibin A

questions.solution:
The pattern of hormones that are expected in a normal menstrual cycle is increasing estradiol in the proliferative phase, FSH surge around the time of ovulation, and high inhibin A levels in the luteal phase.

Hormone Proliferative/follicular phase

Around the time of ovulation

 Luteal/secretory phase
Estradiol

The estrogen levels tend to increase progressively in the proliferative phase

 

 36 to 48 hours before the ovulation, it reaches a maximal concentration to cause LH surge

Due to the production from the corpus luteum, the estradiol levels are higher in the initial to mid-luteal phase.

Once the corpus luteum starts involuting, their levels fall.
Progesterone very low low Due to the production from corpus luteum, their levels reach a maximal concentration
FSH Due to the secretion from the anterior pituitary, the FSH levels increase moderately. This causes the growth and development of the follicles The FSH levels also increase at the time of ovulation about twofold to threefold from the baseline Under the strong inhibitory effects of the estrogen secreted from corpus luteum, their levels tend to be lower
LH The levels of LH increase only minimally by secretion from the anterior pituitary Due to the positive feedback by estrogen, the levels of LH surge to the highest possible levels. This is very essential for the ovulation to happen Similar to LH, once its function of luteinizing is complete, their levels start decreasing
Inhibin A Low Increased Inhibin A is also secreted from the corpus luteum and hence increased
Inhibin B

During the earlier days of the follicular phase inhibit B levels are low.

After this, when the follicles mature, the granulosa cells secrete inhibit B, increasing their levels. 

 There is a postovulatory peak  Decreased

questions.text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia, how do you best measure his temperature?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario rectal temperature would be the preferred site to measure the core body temperature.

During the low or high temperatures like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highly misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperatures

Infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is the representative of core body temperature. However, more often the thermometer is not inserted adequately or for safety reason they are manufactured in such a way that they do not reach deep into ear canal or contains cerumen which can disturb the measurement. Hence the infrared thermometer more commonly delivers the temperature of ear canal, cerumen and hence not a reliable method of measuring the core body temperature.

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, _____________.

choices.text: B  fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.solution:
The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

Sleeping for a long period with the arms under the head puts pressure on a nerve, leading to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact. A fibers (includes the motor fibers) are affected.

The susceptibility of the nerve fibers to pressure are A>B>C.

This is responsible for saturday night or sunday morning paralysis.

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as 'B'?
questions.solution:
The part of the gut marked by 'B' is the anterograde segment, which is in a state of relaxation. The vasoactive intestinal peptide is responsible for bringing relaxation in this part of the gut.

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. It moves in oral to caudal direction.

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

NOTE:

In achalasia cardia, there is decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: The image below shows finding seen on eliciting plantar reflex in a patient in the neurology ward. All of the following signs may be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign), suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Fasciculations are seen in lower motor neuron lesions (not UMN).

Babinski sign refers to dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. It is a sign of upper motor neuron lesion. In normal adults, the response is plantar flexion of the toes.

 

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot.

The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

 

Other signs as seen in patients with UMN lesions are spasticity, hypertonia and hyperreflexia. 

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting . UMN lesions result in weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: A histology slide of the adrenal gland is provided below. Which of the following hormones is secreted from the zone marked as D?

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus

A lesion in this region leads to motor/Broca's aphasia. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. The speech is impoverished in function words that contribute to the syntax but is enriched in meaningful nouns and verbs. However, comprehension of speech is intact and the patient knows what he wants to say.

For example, a patient with Broca's aphasia may say "walk dog" instead of "I want to take the dog for a walk".

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.

The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava. From here, the blood enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This mixed blood is distributed to the body via aorta. 

Therefore, inferior vena cava has the highest concentration of oxygen in the fetal circulation.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

questions.text: The part marked "x" in the image given below consists of all except ______
questions.solution:
The part marked "x" in the image does not contain myosin.

Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere:

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
    • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
    • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
    • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to his primary-care clinician complaining of erectile dysfunction. He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain an erection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the following vasoactive mediators would primarily be prolonged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The action of nitric oxide would primarily be prolonged in this patient.

Sildenafil: It is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, which inhibits cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging the action of NO.

Penile erection is produced by release of nitric oxide (NO), with consequent vasodilation and engorgement of the corpora cavernosa.

questions.text: Prosopagnosia is
questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize familiar faces

  • Autotopagnosia -  inability to recognize or to orient any part of one's own body
  • Simultagnosia - inability to recognize multiple elements in a visual presentation, one object or some elements of a scene can be appreciated but not the display as a whole
  • Somatagnosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one’s own or another’s body
  • Tactile agnosia (aka stereognosia) -  inability to recognize objects by touch, in the presence of intact cutaneous and proprioceptive hand sensation; caused by a lesion in the contralateral parietal lobe

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child with the complaints that he hasn't begun walking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.

Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include:

  • Strabismus
  • Photophobia
  • Nystagmus
  • Impaired vision or blindness
  • Astigmatism

Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. She was given folate 5mg and the blood picture improved. However, the neurologic manifestations were aggravated. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.solution:
The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores aggravating symptoms.

The patient described presented with megaloblastic anemia. The most common causes include vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency. This patient has been empirically treated with folate supplements.

Administration of folic acid can partially reverse some of the hematologic abnormalities associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.

Administration of folic acid to an individual with vitamin B12 deficiency can potentially mask untreated vitamin B12 deficiency or even worsen the neurologic complications. Hence, testing for and/or treatment of vitamin B12 deficiency is required in all patients being treated with folic acid.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole.  He developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. The blood picture is given below. The most likely diagnosis is  __________
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in persons with G6PD deficiency.

Other options:

  • The hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury which commonly occurs following gastroenteritis with E.Coli O157: H7.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and PNH are not precipitated by exposure to cotrimoxazole. AIHA maybe secondary to SLE, lymphomas, EBV, CMV or Mycoplasma infections. Stress and infections can precipitate PNH.

Drugs that carry risk of clinical hemolysis in persons with G6PD Deficiency:

antibiotics

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea.  On further evaluation, the patient was found to have cutaneous flushing, extensive wheeze, and tricuspid insufficiency. Contrast enhanced-MRI revealed the presence of endocardial fibrosis. Which of the following substances will be excreted excessively in this patient?
questions.solution:
5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) will be excreted excessively in the above given clinical scenario, as this is a case of carcinoid syndrome.

Carcinoid syndrome is due to excessive production of serotonin, a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism. It is then metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA. It is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhoea. 

Note:

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific to carcinoid tumours. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumours associated with carcinoid syndrome.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented to OPD  with multiple pigmented papular lesions on her face, neck, and forearm and corneal injection following exposure to the sun. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and the history is suggestive of Xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is  Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER).

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

The given image shows hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with features as shown below:
questions.solution:
The image provided is characteristic of Casal's necklace, seen in pellagra, and indicates a deficiency of Tryptophan.

Pellagra can occur due to:

  • Vitamin B3 (niacin)
    • Niacin is derived from tryptophan and needs B2 and B6 for its synthesis.
  • Hartnup's disease (tryptophan malabsorption)
  • Malignant carcinoid syndrome (↑ tryptophan metabolism)
  • Isoniazid (↓ vitamin B6)

In Hartnup's disease, defective membrane transport of tryptophan across PCT and enterocytes leads to malabsorption of tryptophan. This causes a deficiency of tryptophan.

As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced and this manifests as pellagra with dermatitis, diarrhea and dementia (3D's) and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called the Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

questions.text: A 1 year and 1 month old child presented with developmental delay with her peripheral smear showing macrocytic anaemia. There is no B12 or folic acid deficiency. The compound given in the picture is excreted in the urine. Her peripheral smear is also given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is orotic aciduria.

Points in favour of orotic aciduria in the case above:

  • Developmental delay
  • Megaloblastic anemia, peripheral smear – hypersegmented neutrophils
  • Absence of B12 and folic acid deficiency
  • The compound given in the picture is Orotic acid which is excreted in urine.

Orotic aciduria: It is a rare autosomal recessive condition, involving error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidines.

  • Type I: Deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl tranferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase).
  • Type II: Deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

Confirmation of diagnosis requires assay of the transferase and decarboxylase enzymes in the patients erythrocytes. Anemia responds promptly to administration of uridine.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came to OPD with a tingling sensation in her legs and hands. The oral examination shows the following features. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing the riboflavin deficiency that this patient has. The image shows cheilosis and angular stomatitis which point towards riboflavin deficiency. The nutritional status of riboflavin can be assessed by measuring the activity of the RBC glutathione reductase.

Deficiency state of riboflavin is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  • Cheilosis: pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips, which extends radially to skin.
  • Glossitis: tongue becomes smooth, loss of papilla (magenta-colored tongue).

  • Other features: Seborrheic dermatitis, anemia.

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome?
questions.solution:
The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.

Clinical relevance: It plays an important role in antigen presentation to T lymphocytes as it degrades viruses and other molecules to small peptides.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from:
questions.solution:
Nitric oxide is synthesized from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalyzed by NO synthase. 

The co-enzymes of NO synthase include FMN, FAD, Heme, and Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins?

choices.text: Primary, secondary and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation
Secondary structure is stabilised by disulphide bonds
Secondary and Tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence

questions.solution:
The tertiary structure is three dimensional is the right answer among the given options. Secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures are 3 dimensional.
 
Structural organization of proteins:

Primary: a linear sequence of amino acids in the polypeptide chain

Secondary: Folded and geometrically ordered units of short segments of polypeptides; example alpha helix, beta-pleated sheets, loops, and bends

Tertiary: Secondary structures arranged into larger functional units

Quaternary: Different types of polypeptides arranged in a spatial manner

Other options

Option B: Protein denaturation results in the unfolding and disorganization of the secondary and tertiary structures without the hydrolysis of peptide bonds, which form the primary structure

Option C: Hydrogen bond and Van der Waal interactions are involved in the stabilization of secondary structure(helix).Disulfide bonds stabilize the tertiary structure of proteins.

Option D: Primary structure depends upon the amino acid sequence.

questions.text: If the percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. What is the percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in the DNA is 22%.

As per the Chargaff's rule, in the DNA molecules, the concentration of deoxyadenosine (A) equals that of thymidine (T), and the concentration of deoxyguanosine (G) equals that of deoxycytidine (C). Therefore, A=T and G=C.

In the question, the concentration of thymine is given as 28%, therefore the concentration of adenine is also 28%, both of which add up to 56%. The remaining 44% (100-56) of the DNA consists of G-C base pairs. Of which the guanine constitutes 22% and the cytosine constitutes another 22%.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals a child with sparse and kinky hair. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia. These features strongly suggest a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase enzyme.

This results from a deficiency of its co-factor i.e copper due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A deficiency: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B deficiency: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: The microscopic finding as shown in the hair strand image is due to the deficiency of which of the following enzyme?
questions.solution:
Microscopic analysis of the hair shaft showing trichorrhexis nodosa and longitudinal breaks and is seen in Argininosuccinic aciduria due to the defect in the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase.

It is a defect in the hair shaft characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily.

Trichorrhexis nodosa can also be caused by other disorders such as:

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Iron deficiency
  • Menkes' kinky hair syndrome

questions.text: The most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is
questions.solution:
The most important source of reducing equivalents (NADPH) for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (HMP) pathway.

Since HMP shunt pathway and fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. This NADPH is involved as a donor of reducing equivalents in both the reduction of the 3-ketoacyl and of the 2,3-unsaturated acyl derivatives. 

Other sources are:

  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

questions.text: In which of the following tissues does gluconeogenesis take place?
questions.solution:
Liver and kidney are the two major locations where gluconeogenesis takes place.

During short periods of fasting, most of gluconeogenesis takes place in the liver, while the remaining takes place in the kidneys. However, during periods of prolonged fasting, the kidneys become a major site of gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis:

  • Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors.
  • Gluconeogenesis occurs in cytosol and mitochondria of the liver and kidney.
  • Significant substrates are glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.
  • Lactate generated in various tissues is transported to the liver and is converted to back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis. This pathway is referred to as Cori’s cycle.
  • Glucose-alanine cycle is referred to as Cahill cycle.
  • Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis since it lacks glucose-6-phosphatase.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is used for the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine?
questions.solution:
Methionine in the form of S-adenosyl methionine is used during the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

The function of S-Adenosyl methionine:

1. Transmethylation reactions:

  • Norepinephrine to Epinephrine
  • Ethanolamine to Choline
  • Acetyl serotonin to Melatonin
  • Guanidinoacetate to Creatine

2.  DNA methylation

3.  Polyamine synthesis:

  • Cadaverine
  • Putrescine
  • Spermidine
  • Spermine

Related Pearl: Metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptom of hemarthrosis and the investigations are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleed. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1- Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3- Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4- Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called?
questions.solution:
The change described in the question is called metaplasia.

Metaplasia is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

Examples of metaplasia include:

  • Columnar to squamous epithelium (also called squamous metaplasia):
    • This is the most common type of metaplasia, and is usually seen in the respiratory tract in cases of chronic smoking or sometimes in vitamin A deficiency,
    • It may also be present in cases where there are stones in the excretory ducts of salivary glands, pancreas, or bile ducts, where, the normal secretory columnar epithelium is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Squamous to columnar epithelium (also called columnar metaplasia): It is seen in Barrett's oesophagus.
  • Connective tissue metaplasia: It refers to the formation of bone, cartilage, or adipose tissue in the tissues where they are normally absent. One such example is myositis ossificans, a condition where there is the formation of bone within the muscle.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle ​cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hurthle cells are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in females between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase in the vast majority of Hashimoto patients.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers.
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles, lined by epithelial cells, which contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These epithelial cells are referred to as Hurthle cells.

questions.text: A 25-year old man presents with the condition given in the image. Which of the following is not associated with the condition in the image?
questions.solution:
The image above depicts gynecomastia in a young male patient. Gynecomastia may be associated with functioning testicular tumors, but not in seminoma.

Gynecomastia occurs as a result of an imbalance between estrogens, which stimulate breast tissue, and androgens, which counteract these effects.

The most common causes are as follows:

  • Cirrhosis of the liver
  • Alcohol
  • Marijuana, heroin
  • Antiretroviral therapy
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Klinefelter syndrome (XXY karyotype)
  • Functioning testicular neoplasms, such as the Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumors.

Microscopically, there is an increase in dense collagenous connective tissue associated with epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micro-papillae. Lobule formation is almost never observed.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.

It is also seen in other conditions such as membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Since the podocytes are affected in these diseases, they are also known as podocytopathies.

The effacement of foot process can only be observed on electron microscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease?

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.solution:
Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel wall.

Pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease:

During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to rectum. The enteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells. In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to the development of distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner submucosal and the Auerbach myenteric plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment. As a result, there is a lack of co-ordination in the peristaltic contractions and functional obstruction, which further leads to the dilation of intestine proximal to the affected segment, leading to congenital megacolon.

Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the absence of ganglion cells in biopsied sections.

Some conditions may cause acquired megacolon. These include:

  • Chagas disease, due to the loss of ganglion cells
  • Visceral myopathy
  • Obstruction by neoplasm or inflammatory stricture
  • Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis.
  • Functional psychosomatic disorders.

questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called:
questions.solution:
A graft from an identical twin is called an isograft.

Isograft is defined as an organ or tissue that is taken from a donor and is transplanted to a recipient who has the same genetic constitution as the donor. For example, graft between identical twins.

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Orthotopic

 

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. 

Diseased organ removed
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. 

Diseased organ kept in place.
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person.

Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in _______:
questions.solution:
Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves.. Aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, however, in some cases, the right heart valves may be involved.

Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. Embolization often occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli.

Related Pearl: Vegetations in Various Types of Endocarditis

questions.text: What is the tell-tale sign of free radical injury?
questions.solution:
Lipochrome is a tell-tale sign of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation. It is also known as wear-and-tear pigment or lipofuscin.

It is an insoluble, brownish yellow, granular intracellular material. It accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain with aging. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.

Given below is a histopathological image of cardiac muscle showing lipofuscin pigmentation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought with enlargement of the right testis. USG shows a 3cm solid mass within the body of the testis. Serum AFP is 230 ng/ml. Orchidectomy specimen revealed a nonencapsulated tumour having a homogeneous, yellow-white, mucinous appearance. The microscopy image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is the yolk sac tumor of the testis (Endodermal sinus tumour). 

The given microscopic image shows a lacelike reticular network of cuboidal tumour cells and Schiller duval bodies.

Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age. In this age group, it has a very good prognosis.

 

Eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules may be present within and outside the cytoplasm in which α-fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin can be demonstrated by immunocytochemical staining.

Histology of yolk sac tumour of the testis showing schiller duval bodies (arrow).

questions.text: The following is the histopathological image of the patient with acute viral hepatitis. Identify the cause of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman bodies.

These are acidophil bodies, which represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis.

Councilman bodies are seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by:
questions.solution:
Flask shaped ulcers are classically seen in amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica.

In amoebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts, and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Amebic Colitis
    • Colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements.
    • Diarrhea associated with tenesmus and heme-positive stool.
    • Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa, produce flask-shaped ulcers.
  • Amebic Liver Abscess
    • Fever is the hallmark of amebic liver abscess
    • It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver.
    • Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, may also occur.
    • The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on ultrasonography,computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.text: Which of these is an oncofetal antigen?
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

  • Valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis and monitoring primary hepatocellular carcinoma, hepatoblastoma, non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors, embryonal carcinoma, teratomas, choriocarcinoma, yolk sac carcinoma, germ cell tumors of the ovary and extragonadal germ cell tumors
  • Hepatoblastoma: an embryonic form has always been found to be associated with grossly elevated serum AFP levels.
  • Regenerated hepatic tissue following liver damage due to viral hepatitis, chemically induced necrosis, and liver surgery are associated with moderately raised serum AFP levels.

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)

  • Normally detected in glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells
  • May play a role in the metastasis of cancer cells
  • CEA levels over 5 ng/dL: ascites fluid A/W malignancy
  • Detection, recurrence, and prognosis of adenocarcinoma (lung) and colorectal carcinoma
  • Elevated levels also present in cirrhosis, biliary obstruction, hepatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, smokers and post-surgical bowel sequestration with mucocele
  • Benign cysts may be CEA+ even when benign
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma: canalicular pattern for polyclonal CEA is 50-90% sensitive for hepatocellular carcinoma, > 95% specific
  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma: 92% sensitive for metastases vs. 0% for bile duct adenoma.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of loose stools. On history taking, he reveals to have consumed food from a restaurant 3 hours back. Which of the following is wrong about the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of an acute episode of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The toxin involved, enterotoxins, are heat stable.

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hours after consuming contaminated food (other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hours is Bacillus cereus-Emetic strains).

Enterotoxin produced by Staphylococcus:

  • There are 15 enterotoxins, they are superantigens
  • It is a preformed toxin that is heat stable (Most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile).
  • Site of action: This toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting centre of the brain and also stimulates the intestinal peristaltic activity.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection. He also developed an erythematous rash on the cheek which progressed to the extremities the following day as shown below. The agent responsible for this condition has ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of erythema infectiosum, also known as the fifth disease, which is caused by Parvoviruses. These are Single-stranded DNA virus.

The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which appears initially as erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance. Later the rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema.

Note:

  • Viruses contain either RNA or DNA but never both.
  • Only single-stranded DNA virus – Parvoviridae
  • Only double-stranded RNA virus – Reoviridae

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutter and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which breaks down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of Foot.

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics.

Phaeohyphomycosis : it is a chronic fungal infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The lesions maybe plaques which are verrucous, hypertkeratotis or ulcerated. The fungi implicated are usually of the class Phialophora or Cladophora or other demetacious fungi.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive​ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.

It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.

It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by:
questions.solution:
Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome. 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent?
questions.solution:
Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.solution:
Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

Functions of pili:

  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produces superantigen?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE), which is a superantigen.

Superantigens are protein toxins that stimulate large numbers of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. They bind to the class II MHC molecule outside the peptide-binding groove and Vβ region of the TCR.

Some examples of superantigens are staphylococcal enterotoxins, toxic shock syndrome toxin, and group A streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin.

The below image shows the binding of superantigen to T-cell receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation?
questions.solution:
The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. HIV-antibody spot test was negative, however p24 antigen assay was positive. You explain to him that he is currently in the window period for HIV. Which of the following statements would you use to explain the concept to him?

choices.text: It is the time period between infection and onset of first symptoms
It is the time period between infection and detection of antibodies
It is the time period between exposure and onset of viral multiplication
It is the time period between exposure and appearance of symptoms

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has experienced a high-risk exposure to HIV due to sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. 

The period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV is known as the window period.

The window period may last anywhere between 2–8 weeks to a few months. During this period, the individual may be highly infectious. HIV infection can be detected during this period by p24 antigen assay and PCR.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses has been depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a filamentous virus, hence, it is most likely to be the Ebola virus. 

Option A: Corona virus has petal/club-shaped peplomers radiating like sunrays.

 

Option B: Adenovirus is space-vehicle shaped.

 

Option D: Rabies virus is bullet shaped.

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at  ______.
questions.solution:
Pasteurization: Milk is heated at either 

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15–20 seconds: the flash process

followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in Holder method.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis?

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/μL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: The senior resident in the emergency medicine department decided to add the diuretic which acts on site "A"  marked in the image to the patient with pulmonary edema. The mechanism of action of this diuretic is __________
questions.solution:
Site " A" is the thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle. Loop diuretics act on the thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle and inhibit Na+- K+ -2Cl- symport.

questions.text: A patient with a complex psychiatric history is on a mono-amine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. She visits her primary care physician with increasing depression. The physician adds a serotonin reuptake inhibitor. (SSRI). Which of the following is she most likely to develop?

choices.text: Fever, rigidity, dilated pupils, and hyperreflexia
Fever, hyporeflexia, rigidity and normal pupils
Fever, normotonia, dilated pupils and normal reflexes
Fever, rigidity, normal pupils and reduced bowel sounds

questions.solution:
This patient, who is on a MAO inhibitor + an SSRI, can develop serotonin syndrome, characterised by fever, rigidity, hyperreflexia and dilated pupils.

Other Options:

Option B: This is seen in neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which occurs due to certain antipsychotics.

Option C: This is seen in anticholinergic toxicity.

Option D: This is seen in malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to your OPD with severe constipation. After ruling out pathological causes, which of the following is the safest to prescribe?
questions.solution:
Lactulose is safe to use in pregnant women with constipation.

Constipation in pregnancy:

Constipation is a common occurrence in pregnancy because of dietary alterations, anatomic impingement of a large uterus on the rectosigmoid, fluid shifts, decreased exercise levels, and reduced mobility. Pregnancy and pregnancy-related constipation increases the risk for developing haemorrhoids.

Treatment options include

  • Dietary changes - increased water intake, increased fibre in diet
  • Gentle exercises
  • Laxatives - Lactulose, an osmotic purgative, and Ispaghula, a bulk forming agent, are safe to use in pregnancy. 

Senna, bisacodyl, docusates and saline laxatives’ safety is unknown and hence it is better to avoid them.

Note:

Laxatives are drugs that promote bowel evacuation.

Classification of Laxatives:

  • Bulk-forming agents 
    • Dietary fibre: Bran
    • Psyllium, Ispaghula, Methylcellulose
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: Phenolphthalein, Bisacodyl, Sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: Senna, Cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: Prucalopride
    • PG analogue: Lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulphate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulphate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose
    • Lactitol
