questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with a complaint of lower backache. The radiographic image of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured and her  T-score is -2.8. She was given oral drugs but she was not strictly compliant with it as she was intolerant to the oral drugs. Which would be the intravenous drug useful for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case and a T-score of -2.8 are suggestive of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Bisphosphonates (Zolindronate 5 mg intravenous annually) are used in the management of postmenopausal osteoporosis, not tolerant to oral drugs.

The above image depicts the ballooning of disc spaces leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body known as ‘Codfish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

Bisphosphonates are analogs of pyrophosphate. They specifically inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Mechanism of action:

Bisphosphonates concentrate at sites of active remodeling. They remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of motion sickness?
questions.solution: Promethazine is used for motion sickness. It is an antihistaminic agent that acts as an antagonist of H1 receptors. It also has central anticholinergic activity that is responsible for its antiemetic action.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs gets deposited in cornea?
questions.solution:
Chloroquine, an anti-malarial drug may get deposited in the cornea leading to corneal opacity.

Ocular toxicity of chloroquine:

  • Short-term therapy - blurring of vision and diplopia, reversible on stoppage of drug.
  • Long-term use (high-dose): 
    • Keratopathy
    • Pigmentary retinopathy
    • Optic atrophy

Hydroxychloroquine has lower ocular toxicity compared to chloroquine. 

Drugs causing corneal opacity:

  • Amiodarone
  • Phenothiazine
  • Indomethacin
  • Chloroquine

Long-term treatment with these drugs can cause a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata. It is also seen in Fabry's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease.

The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive and fatal. Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/day or more, and recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia appear to be risk factors for this condition.

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.text: A  patient with gout develops hypertension.  The uric acid level was found to be elevated. Which of the following is not administered?
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazides are not given to this patient.

Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. Hydrochlorothiazides inhibit renal Ca2+ excretion causing hypercalcemia and may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients.

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

For intravenous use, 1:1000 adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:10,000 and should be used very cautiously as slow bolus.

There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by either inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline. Hence, IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias).

For intramuscular, subcutaneous, and inhalational (nebulization) routes of administration, 1:1000 dilution can be used. 

In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV use. The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of 1:10,000 solution IV administered every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines.

Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics and to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoing treatment for TB visits your OPD for follow-up. His wife states that recently he is forgetting the names of his colleagues and neighbors, but later recollects them correctly. Which drug is implicated to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is the antitubercular drug that is implicated in the causation of transient memory loss.

Neurological toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuritis, and seizures can occur with isoniazid therapy. It is also associated with abnormalities like:

  • Euphoria
  • Transient memory loss
  • Separation of ideas and reality
  • Loss of self-control
  • Florid psychosis

Pyridoxine therapy can prevent and reverse most of the neurological toxicity and mental abnormalities.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action Blocks mycolic acid synthesis. Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis. Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane. Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: The graph shows the drug-receptor interaction. Identify the line that depicts action of the antagonist.
questions.solution:
Line C depicts the action of an antagonist.

The receptor is postulated to exist in two forms: the inactive form (Ri) and the activated form (Ra). An antagonist binds to Ri and Ra in relative same amounts as in the absence of any drug (Ri~Ra). Thus, in this situation, no change in activity is observed (Line C).

The presence of the antagonist at the receptor site will block access of agonists to the receptor and prevent the agonist effect. Such blocking action is termed as neutral antagonism, for example, flumazenil on GABA receptors.

Other options:

  • Line A depicts full agonist, where the drug shifts maximum receptors to Ra pool. (Ra>>Ri)
  • Line B depicts partial agonists, which bind to the same receptors and activate them but not as much as full agonists, even at their maximum concentrations.
  • Line D depicts inverse agonists, where the majority of the receptors are shifted to inactivated state than activated state (Ri>Ra). Here, the effects are opposite to those produced by conventional agonists at that receptor.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles?

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.solution:
Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis.

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Azole antifungals are of two types:

  • Imidazoles - clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazoles - itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole and isavuconazole

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Lithium usage in pregnancy can lead to which of the following teratogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Lithium use in pregnancy can lead to cardiac defects. 

Ebstein's anomaly is the specific cardiac defect with lithium use in pregnancy.

In Ebstein’s anomaly, the radiological sign seen is a box-shaped heart.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of ingestion of one uncrushed seed similar to that shown in the image below. He is asymptomatic at presentation. Which of the following can be anticipated in this case?
questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos-nux vomica. If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action, as they are not dissolved in the gastrointestinal tract, and are passed entirely in the faeces.

Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postsynaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed.

Patients typically present with symptoms similar to tetanus such as

  • Convulsions are clonic initially but eventually become tonic. The anti-gravity muscles experience the most severe convulsions, causing the body to typically arch in hyperextension—a position called opisthotonus.
  • Risus sardonicus which results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back.
  • If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleurosthotonus).
  • If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

The first step in the management of strychnine poisoning is to control convulsions with benzodiazepines or barbiturates and the patients should be placed in a dark room to avoid triggering further convulsions. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb unabsorbed poison after a thorough stomach wash. Acidification of urine can be done to increase the excretion of strychnine.

The toxin strychnine does not affect any receptors in the brain and the person remains conscious till death. Strychnine poisoning is characterized by conscious seizures. 

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

  • Mnemonic to remember signs and symptoms.
  • We know that CRAMPing of muscles leads to the exhaustive death of the person in strychnine poisoning. Therefore:
    • Convulsions
    • Reflex increased
    • Awful taste
    • Mind is conscious
    • Pupils dilated
  • Clonic-tonic convulsions
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus: fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Medico-legal implications:.

  • Although a poison, in relatively low doses can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Strychnine plant

Strychnine seeds

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is Barberio test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Other options: 

Option B: Florence test: 

  • The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide.
  • A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip.
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Option C: Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. Small piece of suspected material is added on a glass slide.
  • Then, 2-3 drops of Takayama reagent is added and covered with a coverslip.
  • If it is a bloodstain, pink feathery crystals of haemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes.

Option D: Teichmann test (Haemin Crystal Test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains.
  • Small piece of suspected material is placed on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.
  • If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear.
  • When hydrogen peroxide is added, the haematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof?

choices.text: Police not under rank of  sub inspector

questions.solution:
In the case of civil negligence, the burden of proof is on the patient.

The question of civil negligence arises when a suit is filed in a civil court:

  • By a patient or his/her relatives against the doctor for getting compensation from the doctor if he/she has suffered an injury due to the doctor's negligence.
  • By a doctor against the patient or his/her relatives to collect the fees, the payment of which has been refused due to alleged professional negligence by the doctor.

In either case, the patient has to prove that the doctor has committed professional negligence. To prove negligence, all the following four elements must be present:

  • Duty: A duty of care by the doctor must exist.
  • Dereliction: The physician must maintain the standard of a 'prudent physician' under similar circumstances. If the physician fails to maintain the standard of care, it is called dereliction.
  • Direct causation: The negligent act or omission must directly cause the injury without any intervening cause.
  • Damage: The negligent act must cause damage of a type that would have been foreseen by a reasonable physician.

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describe the symptoms seen classically in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait which is neurotoxic and can cause muscle paralysis. 

Clinical features of bites of Elapidae (cobras, kraits, mambas, coral snakes) present in a similar pattern. The local bite reaction is generally mild with oozing of bloodstained fluid. There is no burning sensation and swelling in the case of Krait bite but present in the case of Cobra bite.

However, their neurotoxic effects are prominent. Systemic symptoms appear after about 30 minutes. The patient feels sleepy, slightly intoxicated, and weakness of legs, and is reluctant to stand or move. Nausea and vomiting are also seen. Cyanosis is very marked.

Paralysis initially presents as ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia, which may appear within a few minutes after the bite or after some hours. Later, paralysis of the muscles of the face, palate, jaws, tongue, and neck can occur. Respiratory failure can occur due to airway obstruction at this stage or later due to paralysis of the intercostal muscles and diaphragm. 

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include: 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Perioral paraesthesia
  • Hyperacusis
  • Dizziness
  • Vertigo
  • Gooseflesh
  • Vomiting
  • Hypersalivation

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Pit viper
  • Saw-scaled viper
 Vasculotoxic

Local reaction

  • severe
  • edema and necrosis

Anticoagulant effect - widespread bleeding

Elapidae

  • Cobra
  • Krait
 Neurotoxic

Local reaction

  • mild

Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (Sea snakes) are now considered subfamily of elapidae

 Myotoxic Generalized rhabdomyolysis

Saw scaled viper:

Green pit viper:

Common krait:

King cobra:

Sea snake:

Two fang marks

A number of small teeth marks in a row

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows postmortem marbling. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins.

Intestinal bacteria infest the venous system as blood acts as a nutrient medium for their proliferation. There is subsequent hemolysis which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to marbling. This becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in the summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

questions.text: The most common drug which causes physical dependence is?
questions.solution:
Heroin is the most common drug which can cause physical dependence.

Physical dependence is defined is a condition where withdrawal of a drug after its prolonged use causes physiological and emotional illness, often referred to as the withdrawal syndrome. Neither physical dependence nor withdrawal symptoms occur with hallucinogens. Although it is necessary to note that a user can develop a psychological dependence on the insight-inducing experiences of episodes of hallucinogen use. Hence, all 3 hallucinogens - ketamine, LSD, and Phencyclidine (PCP) does not cause physical dependence

According to the world drug report 2019, released by the United Nations office on drugs and crime (UNODC), the most common drugs used across the world (in decreasing order) include:

  • Cannabis
  • Opioids
  • Amphetamine and prescription stimulants
  • Ecstacy
  • Cocaine

Among the opioids, the commonly used group of drugs are opiates which include drugs like opium, morphine, and heroin.

 

The prefrontal cortex powers the ability to exert self-control over impulses. This is also the last part of the brain to mature, making teens most vulnerable. Shifting balance between this circuit and the circuits of the basal ganglia and extended amygdala make a person with a substance use disorder seek the drug compulsively with reduced impulse control.

questions.text: In the case of rape of a young child, the hymen is usually

choices.text: Ruptured since it is superficially situated
Ruptured since it is very thin
Unruptured since it is deeply situated
Unruptured since it is highly elastic

questions.solution:
In the case of a young child, the hymen is deeply situated and usually intact after intercourse.  

In children, the hymen is deeply situated, and as the vagina is very small, it is impossible for the penetration of the adult organ to take place.

In children, there are a few or no signs of general violence, as the child is unaware of the assault and incapable of resisting. A few indicators for routine enquiry are pain on urination and/or defecation, abdominal pain, inability to sleep, sudden withdrawal from peers/adults, feelings of anxiety, nervousness, helplessness, weight loss, and feelings of ending one’s life.

questions.text: The following image shows the resulting wound cavity from a  bullet.  Which of the following explains the shape of the wound cavity?
questions.solution:
The shape of the wound cavity can be explained by yawing of the bullet. 

Yawing is a common phenomenon seen with bullets (not with spheres). It is the rotation of the bullet around a lateral axis while passing through dense media such as tissues. 

The angle between the trajectory and the long axis of the bullet increases due to destabilising forces until it reaches 90 degrees , i.e., the bullet’s long axis is perpendicular to the trajectory. The yawing motion then continues until 180 degrees and the bullet will remain in this stable position where the base is the leading part.

The path of a projectile in a dense medium therefore shows three distinct sections, depending on the respective cross sectional area: narrow channel, increased cavities, and tail end.

 

Tracking produced by a yawing bullet.

Peculiar phenomena seen with bullets:

Tandem bullet (also called piggyback bullet): This is where two bullets come out with a single shot. Seen with unused or locally made weapons. It may cause confusion with the number of entry and exit wounds.

Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge): It is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

Ricochet : This is when the bullet hits an intervening object before hitting the desired target. Due to this, it tumbles towards the target and enters it obliquely, rather than head-on.

Souvenir bullet : When bullets are allowed to remain in the body, fibrous tissue is deposited around them. Then, these are called souvenir bullets. It may lead to chronic lead poisoning. They can be visualized on X-ray.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses have the haematology findings given below?
questions.solution:
The findings present in the above hematology slide are basophilic stippling  (punctate basophilia) with Cabot’s ring . They are features seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism).

Chronic lead poisoning also referred to as plumbism or saturnism occurs following inhalation of lead dust or vapors that arise as a result of burning of paints, batteries, smouldering, glass blowing, and polishing

Clinical features include:

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy
  • E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma)
  • F - Facial pallor -earliest sign

Diagnosis is mainly by history and clinical findings. Increased urinary lead and porphyrin excretion are suggestive of chronic lead poisoning. Radiograph, erythrocyte porphyrin assays, and basophilic stippling in the peripheral smear are also useful.

Prophylaxis in the form of proper ventilation, personal hygiene, periodic medical examination, supplementation of calcium-rich diet and sulphuric acid in the water, and weekly saline purgative in factory works is useful. 

Management includes British Anti-Lewisite, or BAL, for severe acute poisoning, with and without encephalopathy; ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) for moderate poisoning; and D-penicillamine in mild cases.

Other Options:

Option A: Minamata disease- Chronic mercury poisoning can show anemia secondary to GI hemorrhage.

Option C: Chronic iron toxicity- In severe cases, can present with leucocytosis and anemia (due to blood loss).

Option D: Arsenic poisoning- Can induce microcytic hypochromic anemia or hemolytic anemia.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

questions.text: Late signs of death are all except:
questions.solution:
Putrefaction, adipocere formation, mummification are late signs of death whereas suggilation/postmortem hypostasis is an early sign of death. 

Immediate signs of death (somatic death):

  • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
  • Cessation of respiration
  • Cessation of circulation

Early signs of death (cellular death):

  • Pallor and loss of elasticity of skin
  • Eye changes
  • Primary flaccidity of muscles
  • Cooling of the body
  • Postmortem lividity/suggilation
  • Rigor mortis

Late signs of death:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess. 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever. 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.solution:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): The Arnold's nerve innervates the skin over a small part of the ear and external auditory canal. In patients with chronic cough, scratching or mechanical stimulation of ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discolouration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment:

  • Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.
  • Surgical debridement
  • Control of underlying predisposing causes.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A 12-month-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever and difficulty in breathing. On examination, the child had biphasic stridor. The lesion in which of the following level will produce this type of stridor?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions at the level of glottis, subglottis (B), and cervical trachea will cause Biphasic stridor.

Stridor is a noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding.
questions.solution:
The image shows Battle's sign.

It is retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone. 

Other options:

Option b: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

Option c: Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness, swelling which is painful.

Option d: The Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis.

questions.text: What is the main use of the instrument seen in the image?

choices.text: Reduction of the fracture of nasal septum
Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone
Punching out bone in DCR procedure

questions.solution:
The instrument seen in the image is Walsham forceps. Walsham is mainly used to reduce bone fracture.

Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum.

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing a direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.  Which of the following is true with respect to the stridor seen in this baby?

choices.text: Increases in prone position and subsides on crying
Subsides on prone position and increases with crying
Subsides both on crying and prone position
Increases with both prone position and crying

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of laryngomalacia, as the image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis and the stridor associated with this condition subsides on placing the child in a prone position but increases with crying.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding or crying. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Treatment of laryngomalacia is mainly conservative, as it self-corrects by the time the child is 2 years of age. Tracheostomy may be required in some cases with severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: What is occipitomental view with open mouth also known as?
questions.solution:
Occipitomental view with open mouth is also called as Water’s view.

Water's view: The patient’s head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward. The mouth is usually kept open, which allows visualising the sphenoid sinus.

Structures seen in Water’s view are:

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Intratemporal fossa

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media?
questions.solution:
Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

Tuberculosis of the ear is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It presents as a painless condition, with foul-smelling discharge from the ear. Multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft are seen.

questions.text: Surgery where one nostril is partially or completely occluded is done for which condition?
questions.solution:
Complete closure of the nostrils (Young's operation) or partial closure of the nostrils (Modified Young's operation) is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

In Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule. They are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa becomes normal, and the crusting is reduced.

In Modified Young's operation, the procedure has been modified to avoid discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. Here the nostrils are only partially closed. The results are the same when compared to Young's operation.

questions.text: A young adult presents with intermittent non-foul smelling mucoid discharge from the left ear for the past few years. Otologic examination revealed a central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: No evidence of bone destruction in CT scans
Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infections are seen
Aural polyp if present, should never be avulsed

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of intermittent mucoid discharge and central perforation of the tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of tubotympanic type of CSOM, which is not associated with cholesteatoma. Atticoantral type is associated with cholesteatoma and it leads to dangerous complications due to its bone-eroding properties. 

Etiology of tubotympanic (benign or safe) type of CSOM:

  • As a sequela of acute otitis media
  • Ascending infection via the eustachian tube
  • Allergic conditions

Bone destruction is not present in this type.

Culture reveals mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection.

Aural polyp if present should be removed and not avulsed before starting local treatment. This is due to the fact that the polyp may be arising from the stapes, facial nerve, or horizontal canal and its avulsion can lead to facial paralysis or labyrinthitis.

Related Pearl: Classification of CSOM

questions.text: The following instrument is used for:
questions.solution:
Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the posteroinferior or anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani.

Cochlear implant:

  • Electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from hearing aid.
  • Principle- surgery to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of cochlea.
  • Indication- bilateral severe to profound deafness
  • Prerequisites- intact 8th nerve and higher auditory pathway
  • Surgical approach- facial recess (posterior tympanotomy) approach

Note: In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy?

choices.text: Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

questions.solution:
Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication for high tracheostomy.

Types of tracheostomy:

 

High

Mid(Normal)

Low

Level

1st tracheal ring

2/3rd tracheal ring

3/4th tracheal ring

Indications

Carcinoma larynx

Routine indications: Foreign body,Head injury resulting in unconsciousness,Laryngeal diphtheria, Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

Laryngo-tracheal stenosis, Juvenile onset respiratory papillomatosis, Crush injury to larynx.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common sinusitis in children?
questions.solution:
The ethmoid sinus is the most common sinus involved in pediatric sinusitis.

It usually occurs when the infection spreads through the lamina papyracea.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the ​squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a negative forced duction test.

The squint may be either comitant or incomitant.

  • Comitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes. 
  • Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes. 

The differences between comitant and incomitant squint are shown in the table below:

Features Comitant squint Incomitant squint
Magnitude of squint Same in all gazes Varies with the gaze
Diplopia Absent Present
Ocular movements Full Restricted
False projection Absent Present
Abnormal head posture Absent Present
Secondary deviation Equal to primary deviation More than primary deviation

The incomitant squint is further divided into two main types: Paralytic and restrictive.

Paralytic squint occurs due to the paralysis of extraocular muscle while restrictive squint is due to the mechanical restriction caused by tight or fibrosed muscle.

Forced duction test(FDT) differentiates between these two types. In this test, the eye is moved mechanically with the help of a foreceps.

  • The test is negative if there is no resistance to the movement. It is seen in a paralytic squint.
  • The test is positive if there is resistance to the movement. It is seen in a restrictive squint.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Features of cavernous sinus thrombosis include early involvement lateral rectus palsy (abducent nerve involvement) since it runs through the cavernous sinus. Oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy occur later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. Other signs are proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in the mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

Options A- Retinoblastoma occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint.

Option B- Orbital pseudotumor presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

Option C- Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy.

Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of both bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state. The main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

Other options-

Option A- Orbital pseudotumor presents with painful eye movements periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia

Option C- Orbital lymphoma usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

Option D- Orbital cellulitis is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

Related Pearl: Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy

Sign Feature
Dalrymple's sign Retraction of the upper lids
von Graefe's sign Lid lag, i.e., when the globe is moved downward, the upper lid lags behind
Griffith Sign Lower lid lag on upward gaze
Enroth's sign Fullness of the eyelids
Stellwag's sign Infrequent blinking
Gifford's sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid
Mobius’ sign Convergence weakness
Joffroy’s sign Lack of wrinkling of the forehead on superior gaze
Jellinek's Sign Abnormal pigmentation of the upper lid

questions.text: Shifting fluid sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
The presence of shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment.

In serous retinal detachment, there is a subretinal accumulation of the serous fluid mostly due to the breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier. When the position of the head is altered, the fluid shifts to the dependent portion. Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration. A retinal tear or preretinal traction is absent.

Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous with substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells. Retinal breaks are also seen.

Traction RD has a concave configuration and breaks are absent. Retinal mobility is severely reduced and shifting fluid is absent.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding indirect ophthalmoscopy?

choices.text: The image produced is erect and real
Condensor needs to be kept very close to the eye

questions.solution:
An indirect ophthalmoscope produces an inverted real image of 3 to 5 times magnification.

Advantages of the binocular indirect ophthalmoscope are:

  • Visualization through hazy media is possible due to strong in built illumination system.
  • Field of view is much larger than direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Examination of peripheral retina up to ora serrata is possible.
  • Depth perception of the lesion is possible due to stereopsis with binocular indirect ophthalmoscope.
  • Visualization of fundus in very high refractive error is also possible, where it may not be possible to focus the lesion with direct ophthalmoscope.
  • A real, Inverted image is formed (Option A).
  • There is an arms distance between the condensing lens and the patient's eye (Option C).

Other options:

Option D: 15 times magnification is seen with a direct ophthalmoscope.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect ophthalmoscopy

FEATURE DIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE  INDIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE
Condensing lens Not required Required
Examination distance As close to the patient's eye as possible At an arm's length
Image Virtual, Erect Real, Inverted
Magnification 15 times 4-5 times
Illumination Not so bright, so not useful in hazy media Bright, so useful in hazy media
Area of the field in focus About 2 disc diameter About 8 disc diameter
Stereopsis Absent Present
Accessible fundus view Slightly beyond equator Up to ora serrata
Examination through hazy media Not possible Possible

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of staphyloma at point D in the given image?
questions.solution:
Degenerative high axial myopia is the most common cause for posterior staphyloma (Point D)

Staphyloma:

  • It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.
  • So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.
  • In the image:
    • A: Intercalary staphyloma
    • B: Ciliary staphyloma
    • C: Equatorial staphyloma
    • D: Posterior staphyloma

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to you with the following lesion over the eye.  All the following statements regarding this condition are true except:

choices.text: It is usually a stationary condition
Associated with deposition of amorphous hyaline material in the conjunctiva
Temopral side is affected first and then the nasal side
There is elastotic degeneration of collagen fibres of conjunctiva

questions.solution:
The image shows pinguecula, which affects the nasal side first and then the temporal side.

Pinguecula is a degenerative condition of the conjunctiva, characterized by the formation of a yellowish-white patch on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus.

Features:

  • Usually found in elderly people, especially those exposed to strong sunlight, dust, wind, etc.
  • There is an elastotic degeneration of collagen fibres of the substantia propria of the conjunctiva, coupled with deposition of amorphous hyaline material in the substance of conjunctiva.
  • It is a stationary condition

Complications of pinguecula include its inflammation, intraepithelial abscess formation and rarely calcification.

No treatment is required. When inflamed, it is treated with topical steroid.

questions.text: The drug increasing uveoscleral flow is?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug, which acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow and thereby lowers the intraocular pressure. 

Mechanism of action: Latanoprost is a prodrug and gets activated during its passage through the cornea. It acts by stimulating the prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles. This leads to the release of matrix metalloproteinases, which increases the uveoscleral outflow.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is seen after ____________.
questions.solution:
Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating trauma

Less frequently, the condition occurs following intraocular surgery, usually multiple vitreoretinal procedures.

Presentation in trauma-induced cases is between 2 weeks and 3 months after initial injury in 65%.

The earliest symptom is blurred near vision in the sympathizing eye. The earliest sign is a retrolental flare in the sympathizing eye. Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes. The fundus shows multifocal choroidal infiltrates develop in the mid-periphery, with sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen–Fuchs nodules (a granuloma situated between Bruch membrane and the RPE).

Treatment

  • Steroids are the basis of treatment. High-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months.
  • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate can be used in resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.
  • Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury prevents the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal ulcer?

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescien dye

questions.solution:
Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.

The signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer.
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetable matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.solution:

Surgical procedures are undertaken after the stabilization of myopia, which usually occurs after 18 years of age.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP).  

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry- the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography- reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

Atypical types of RP are as follows:

  • Sectoral RP
  • Pericentric/Inverse RP
  • RP sine pigmento
  • RP punctata albescens

There is no effective treatment for RP.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the pupillary light reflex pathway?
questions.solution:
The lateral geniculate body is not a part of the pupillary reflex pathway. It is part of the accommodation reflex and the visual pathway.

Pupillary light reflex pathway:

  • First neurons (sensory) connects each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi.
  • Second neurons (internuncial) connects each pretectal nucleus to both Edinger–Westphal nuclei.
  • Third neurons (preganglionic motor) connects the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion.
  • Fourth neurons (postganglionic motor) leaves the ciliary ganglion and passes in the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae.

Image: Pupillary reflex pathways

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Iris epithelium is not derived from surface ectoderm. It is derived from neural ectoderm.

Lens, corneal epithelium, and conjunctival epithelium are all derivatives of surface ectoderm.

questions.text: In compound myopic astigmatism, with parallel rays of light entering the eye in relaxed accommodation, the image(s) formed is/are __________.

choices.text: One focal point in front of the retina
Two focal lines in front of the retina
Two focal lines behind the retina
Two focal lines, one behind and the other in front of retina

questions.solution:
In compound myopic astigmatism, parallel rays of light enter the eye in relaxed accommodation; therefore, two focal lines are formed in front of the retina.

Option A: One focal point in front of retina: describes myopia

Option C: Two focal lines behind the retina: Describes compound hypermetropic astigmatism

Option D: Two focal lines, one behind and one in front of the retina: Describes mixed astigmatism

questions.text: An employee diagnosed with TB gets extended sickness benefit for:
questions.solution:
Extended sickness benefit is given for a period of 2 years.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding

  • Defense 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage 
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- no cash benefit, full medical care is provided.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of daily wage for a duration of 91 days in one year 
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years for 34 specified diseases 
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
  • Maternity Benefit – Benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy
  • Dependance Benefit– is at 90% daily wages, lifelong for the spouse and parents and till the age of 18 years for any dependant's child, however, the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter is married earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits – temporary disability – is as long as the person is disabled at 90% daily wages. Permanent disability – the lifetime pension 
  • Funeral Benefit – Rs.15,000/-
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs. 10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from workman compensation act 
  • Exemption from maternity benefit act 
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition (Page no: 877)

https://www.esic.nic.in/information-benefits.

questions.text: In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index:

  • The pearl index is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).
  • Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure
  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that is used as the numerator must include every known conception, whatever its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher order births.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: The standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with a measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups are being tested, or more than 2 groups.
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

The tests:

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A person wants to study about the relationship between smoking and lung cancer, so he collects data about people diseased with lung cancer from government hospitals and the number of cigarette packets sold at the same time period. Which type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The type of study described is an ecological study as the unit of study is the population. The number of cigarette packets sold at the same time is data about the population.

Option A: The unit of study in a cross-sectional study is an individual.

Option C: There is no experiment done here. Hence, it is not experimental study.

Option D: Quasi-experiments are nonrandomized, pre-post intervention studies done when it is not feasible or ethical to conduct a randomized controlled trial. The unit of study is therefore patients or individuals and not population.

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: A patient comes with a ​history of clean-cut injury which is not lacerated. He says that he received his last dose of tetanus vaccination about 10 years ago. What should be given next?
questions.solution:
A single dose of tetanus toxoid is given as the wound is clean and the last dose was received more than 10 years ago.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

  1. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.
  2. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.
  3. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.
  4. Unknown or never taken immunization

B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose

questions.text: A 24-month-old child weighing 11 kg was brought to the pediatric OPD. He had a respiratory rate of 38/min. On examination, chest indrawing was observed. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre  immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, it appears that the child has pneumonia as diagnosed from the presence of chest indrawing. The next best step of management is to give oral amoxicillin for five days and send the child home.

This is based on the revised WHO classification and treatment of childhood pneumonia at health facilities. Pneumonia with general danger signs like inability to drink, persistent vomiting, convulsions, lethargic or unconscious, stridor in a calm child or severe malnutrition needs antibiotics with urgent referral to higher centre.

The following image distinguishes the previous and revised classification and treatment of the childhood pneumonia.

World Pneumonia Day, marked every year on 12 November, to raise awareness about the toll of pneumonia – a leading killer of children around the world – and to advocate for global action to protect against, help prevent and effectively treat this deadly illness.

questions.text: A 20 yr old man presents with fever and malaise for 4 days. He has also noticed a rash for the past 2 days. It was initially on his back, but then it appeared on his arms and legs too. On examination, he is febrile and has a pleomorphic rash with areas of papules, vesicles and a few crusts. He is very worried about spreading this infection to his family members and would like to know how long he should isolate himself to prevent this. What do you tell him?

choices.text: Until he finishes a course of acyclovir

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has chickenpox and needs to isolate himself until all the lesions are crusted, which takes approximately 6 days from onset of rash. Only symptomatic treatment is needed in this case. Acyclovir is recommended only if administered within 24 hours.

 

The period of infectivity is from ~48 h before the onset of the vesicular rash, during the period of vesicle formation that generally lasts 4–5 days, and until all vesicles are crusted.

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

Duration of Isolation

Until all lesions are crusted – 6 days usually.

From onset of catarrhal stage to 7 days of rash.

Cholera, diphtheria

 

3 days after tetracycline start until 48 hours.

Shigellosis and salmonellosis

 

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

3 weeks.

Influenza

 

3 days after onset.

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

Until swelling subsides.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is based on behavioral sciences?
questions.solution:
Management by objective is based on behavioral sciences.

Management methods used in health programmes are either quantitative or based on behavioral sciences.

Methods based on behavioral sciences include: 

  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Quantitative methods include:

  • Cost-benefit analysis
  • Cost-effective analysis
  • Cost–accounting
  • Input-output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis - includes programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) and critical path method (CPM)
  • Planning–programming–budgeting system (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the median +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Median +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

95% of population lies between Median+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240

99% of population lies between Median+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.
  • Normal distributions are defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation.
  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.
  • All normal distributions are symmetric and have bell-shaped density curves with a single peak.
  • Exactly half of the values are to the left of the centre and the other half to the right.
  • The total area under the curve is 1.
  • The density of a normal distribution is more around the centre and less around the tails.
  • There is no skew in the curve.
  • Looking at the figure below, we can understand the empirical rule of a normal distribution which states that:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 1 SD).
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD).
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD).
  • Many data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution.
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

questions.text: Which of the following was launched to ensure complete immunization of children?
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, to achieve the same goal by December 2018. 

Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: All of the following diseases are transmitted by the vector shown in the image except:
questions.solution:
Scrub typhus is not caused by the vector shown in the image (tick).

The vector shown is a hard tick and transmits tick typhus, viral encephalitis (e.g., Russian spring-summer encephalitis), viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever), viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. KFD in India), tularemia, tick paralysis, and babesiosis.

The following image shows a soft tick.

Scrub typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mite which is as shown below.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are the hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • General morphology of ticks includes an oval shaped body, four pairs of legs and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in front. Absent.
Head Situated at anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body, ventrally. Not visible from above.
Spiracles Situated behind coxa IV. Situated between III and IV coxa.
Eggs Several hundred/thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Can’t stand starvation; feed night and day. Can stand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Q fever(reservoir), relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion and toxaphone. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: In the following flowchart representing natural history of disease, The duration between point A to B is called as?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the first critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called lead time.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening which is the period between diagnosis by early detection and diagnosis by other means.

questions.text: The given phenomenon is not shown by _____
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the Iceberg phenomenon of disease. It is not shown by Measles.

Diseases like tuberculosis, diabetes, malnutrition, anemia, hypertension, mental illnesses show the iceberg phenomenon of disease.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

Iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B

Note: Rubella shows a large number of subclinical infections. Thus, it is considered to show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman from Assam presented with fever and chills recurring every 48 hours. On examination, she was conscious, oriented, and febrile. CBC, LFT, and RFT were normal. Peripheral smear revealed the following. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing crescent-shaped gametocytes are suggestive of uncomplicated falciparum malaria. As this woman is from a North-Eastern state, the drug regimen of choice is ACT-AL (artemisinin combination therapy): 

  • Artemether (20mg)
  • Lumefantrine (120mg)  

This regimen is followed in the North-Eastern states of India due to documented resistance to sulphadoxine-pyrimethamine in these areas. ACT-AL is contraindicated in:

  • 1st trimester of pregnancy
  • Children < 5 kg

questions.text: You are a medical practitioner in a remote rural area, you remove a worm from a patient as shown below by rolling it over a stick. The worm that you are removing by this procedure is ____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the way Guinea worm(Dracunculiasis) is removed by rolling them out over a small stick.

Dracunculiasis/Guinea worm disease is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by Dracunculus medinenesis. Transmission occurs by consumption of water containing cyclops harbouring infective stages of the parasite. This disease is totally a water-based disease and has no alternate way of transmission.

The life cycle of Guinea worm:

Guinea-worm disease is amenable to eradication. 

  • Worms are removed by sequentially rolling them out over a small stick.
  • Wet compresses may relieve discomfort. Occlusive dressings improve hygiene and limit shedding of infectious larvae.
  • No drug cures the infection but metronidazole and mebendazole are sometimes used to limit inflammation and facilitate worm removal.
    • Provision of safe drinking water (e.g., piped water, installation of hand pumps).
    • Control of cyclops
  • Health education of the public in matters relating to boiling or sieving drinking water through a double thickness cotton cloth for personal protection, and prevention of water contamination by infected persons.
  • Surveillance: Active search for new cases.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

questions.text: The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non exposed is given by which of the following variables?
questions.solution:
The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed is given by attributable risk.

Attributable risk is often expressed as a percentage.

Related Pearl: Relative and attributable risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR >1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 or higher indicates a >/=100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ c/(c+d)] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: The first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit is called as _________
questions.solution:
A primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.

Other options:

  • An index case is the first case of the disease that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.
  • A suspect case is a case that has all the clinical features of the disease but has not been diagnosed with it.
  • A secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case.
